September 26, 1956
Mrs, Judith Stevens, Newsletter Editor
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
14 Gregory Hall
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Mrs, Stevens:
I have your note of September 21st concerning the Prix Italia Award.
I am enclosing herewith a copy of the letter that I sent to Mr. Schooley which gives
background information on the entire Prix Italia. I do not think that this material
should be necessarily published. 'Die information that should be of interest to you
is that there were twelve (12) musical entries and three (3) documentary entries
submitted to the International Relations Committee of NAEB. I arranged for special
juries here in New York to listen to the entries and the Music Jury decided that the
entry from the University of Indiana, "The Ruby" by Norman Dello Joio was the best
one to represent the United States. The Documentary Jury picked the Tony Schwartz
production of "Sounds of My City" which was presented on WNYC. The documentary entry
won the Italian Press Association Prize of one million liras' The program, along with
the other prize-winning programs, will be made available to the NAEB Tape Network
for distribution to member stations.
Tony Schwartz is a young man (in his middle thirties) who has spent
the last eleven (11) years carrying a tape recorder about with him in the same fashion
that you or I might carry a camera. He has some 45,000 sounds of New York City. He
recently was one of the producers of a section of the program on "Wide, Wide World"
over the NBC Television Network. He has had documentary programs broadcast over
CBS and over Mutual. He first appeared on the radio on WNYC a half a dozen years ago.
This represents the second year in a row that an NAEB American Entry has won a prize.
This is in the nature of some sort of a record. Next year because NAEB will be on the
Music Jury, musical entries by NAEB will be out. There will be an opportunity, however,
for member stations of NAEB to submit entries in the field of drama and in the docu¬
mentary field.
NAEB is represented at the Prix Italia General Assembly by
Mr. Bernard Buck, Program Director on leave of absence from WNYC and presently NAEB's
Fulbright Scholar in Rome. It was represented on the jury by Miss Ruby Mercer who
conducts the program, 'Mr. and Mrs. Opera" on WNYC* and has a daily program on W0R.
Miss Mercer has gone on from Italy to Israel where she will be recording several
special programs especially in the field of music.
